user.biography:
"The more you are like yourself, the less you are like anyone else, which makes you UNIQUE." - Walt Disney
•-•-•-•-•-•-•-•-•-•-•-•-•-•-•-•-•-•-•-•-•-•

node.text:
November 14th marks the birthday of the man who co-discovered insulin, Frederick Banting. Banting discovered insulin in 1922, alongside Charles Best.

Today also happens to be my daughters’ birthday, one of whom was diagnosed with Type 1 Diabetes in her early 20s.

Who else is a #Type1Warrior?

node.text:
As we begin to think about what we want our classrooms to look like in the fall (assuming we’re back!), @edutopia created this helpful guide for decorating your classroom with 5 quick tips.

Number 4 speaks to my 10 year old self and her abhorrence for her fourth grade teacher’s spelling scores bulletin board.

But as a self-proclaimed #typeBteacher, I need to work on Number 1.

Which of these are things you already do in your classroom? Which are areas that you should work on?

#uniqueteachertip #teachingtips #classroomdecorations #iteachtoo •

node.title: DOs and DON’Ts of Classroom Decorations

 </Period>
</MPD>

node.text:
Seeing everyone’s Back to School posts right now while I still have weeks left of summer break has me channeling my inner Lucille Bluth.

Okay, so when are YOU going back to school? Or did you go back already?

node.text:
June: “Let me just rest my eyes…” 🥱 August: 😲

We got out in mid-June, so our first day of school isn’t until after Labor Day. When do you go back?

🎨 :: @chibirdart

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Amy • 3rd Grade Teacher on July 29, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'REALLY RESPECT THE TEACHERS WHO CHANGE THEIR BULLETIN BOARD BACKGROUNDS BECAUSE THEY DECIDED TO GO WITH A NEW THEME THIS YEAR. Y'ALL ARE CRAZY, BUT RESPECT YOU.'.

node.text:
▪️My theme must be “Black fabric goes with everything.”▪️

I’ve had the same “theme” for probably a decade because #typeBteacher 🙃 How often do you change your bulletin boards backgrounds?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Amy • 3rd Grade Teacher on July 28, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text.

node.text:
🎧🤯 Have you ever listened to a podcast and wanted to jot down notes on something you heard but didn’t have a paper or pencil, or you were in the middle of doing something else and couldn’t stop? ALL. THE. TIME.

I can’t remember where I heard about the Airr app that lets you “highlight” audio but it’s life-changing 🙌🏻

Swipe to see it in action. Basically just tap the quotes button to mark a 45-second section of the audio. It lets you name it, but if you’re busy you can do that later.

🎧 What are your favorite podcasts?

⭐️ My favorite education podcasts:
🤓 The Cult of Pedagogy
📖 Read Aloud Revival
🧠 The Executive Function Podcast
🧠 Learn Smarter

⭐️ Other top podcasts:
🧠 Hidden Brain
😊 The Happiness Lab

#notanadjustafan •

Photo shared by Amy • 3rd Grade Teacher on July 27, 2021 tagging @theweekjuniorus. May be an image of 2 people, people standing and book.

node.text:
Every summer is the Summer of Reading 🙌🏻☀️ I spend all school year helping kids to develop a love of reading, and The Week Junior’s “Best Kids’ Books for Summer” list supports that!

@theweekjuniorus weekly news magazine for kids ages 8-14 is FULL of articles on all the topics kids love, like Science, Technology, Animals, Movies and Books! And with all that’s happening here and around the world, each issue includes plenty of national and world news.

This “Summer of Reading” issue #63 includes a list of “Best Kids’ Books for Summer.” It’s a mix of new books, classic books, and (my favorite part!) books of all genres. The list is created with top literacy experts, librarians, and educators, and, most importantly, a diverse group of children.

If you’re like me and can’t wait to share this magazine with your students, tap the link in my bio to subscribe!

#SummerofReading #Ad •

https://subscribe.theweekjunior.com/servlet/ConvertibleGateway?cds_mag_code=TWJ&cds_page_id=256647&cds_response_key=P1GRPIRO7

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Amy • 3rd Grade Teacher on July 25, 2021.

node.text:
What’s one thing you implemented during crisis teaching that you’ll continue to do because it’s just good practice?

I displayed these Mindful Breathing visuals as reminders for my students (and me!) as we practiced them together, and then made individual cards on binder rings that I gave to each of them for personal reference.

🖤 UPDATE: I uploaded this resource to my blog! Tap the link in my bio or go to http://bit.ly/UniqueBreathing

Photo by Amy • 3rd Grade Teacher on July 22, 2021. May be an image of indoor.

node.text:
Mornings are crazy enough trying to get attendance AND lunch count in on time. I learned a long time ago that this wasn’t my job. (Well, okay, *technically* it IS my job, but you get me).

My team captains make sure their teammates are in school and have made their lunch choice so all I have to do is glance at our communication board before submitting attendance and lunch 🤪🙌🏻

I considered updating these numbers but decided against it since I have bigger curriculum tasks to tackle and “only” six weeks left of summer! 🤓 When do you go back to school?

Photo by Amy • 3rd Grade Teacher on July 19, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'NIQUE dassreem Amy @uniqueclassroom have good days. I have bad days. Mostly have "doing my best" days. I may not be perfect, but I'm a good teacher who wants the best fo her students.'.
Photo by Amy • 3rd Grade Teacher on July 18, 2021. May be an image of text.

node.text:
The one classroom management strategy you’ll actually stick with 💵⭐️💳
⭐️ If you utilize a classroom economy system with your students, you should consider tying it to your behavior expectations.
⭐️ When I first started using a classroom economy, I was doing all the work: keeping track of infractions, stopping lessons to hand out tickets or other tokens for good behavior, and then taking time away from class to allow students to “purchase” their prizes that I bought.
⭐️ I knew something wasn’t right but struggled to find a better system. Swipe to read how I implement this management plan. It sounds simple, and it is. You do have to let go of some control over it. You have to trust that you’ve put responsible students in team captain positions, and that your students are sincere about their earnings. But I’ve found that third graders are generally a very honest bunch.
⭐️ This system won’t solve all your behavior issues. Some kids just don’t “buy in” to any type of external reward system. Many kids need more from their teacher. They need us to establish relationships, build trust, and reframe our thinking. But in my experience for the majority of my kids, this works!
•
#uniqueclassroomeconomy •

node.text:
📝 Are you even a teacher if you don’t use CHECKLISTS in your classroom?
•
I’ve been using these revising and editing checklists for a few years and I can’t emphasize enough the difference they make in my students’ writing. Not only are the kids required to identify each feature in their own writing, but these checklists help me when I’m ready to grade! 🤯 Color-coded, anyone?! 🟥🟧🟨🟩🟦🟪
•
This resource includes 39 unique checklists for 7 different forms of writing, and includes an EDITABLE version, too! 🤫 (And they’re only a dollar!)
•
Check out bit.ly/UniqueWritingChecklists or tap the link in my bio to see what I’m making such a fuss about!
•
Writing Checklists for Seven Forms of Writing 🗒✍🏻 includes:
•Color-coded Checklists for Revising and Editing 7 Types of Writing
•Black-and-white Checklists for Revising and Editing 7 Types of Writing
•Editable Checklists for Revising and Editing 7 Types of Writing
•A choice of identical Checklists or corresponding Revising and Editing Checklists on each page

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Amy • 3rd Grade Teacher on July 14, 2021. May be an image of child.

node.text:
😌💭 I’m still thinking about how glad I am that I was able to do many of the special “typical” EoY things after such an atypical year. Reading this book is just one of them.

Bamboozled is a super silly book that makes kids giggle on every page, and surprises them at the end 🤪

They always ask to look at the book on their own to pick up details they missed the first time 🤔

As much as this would be a great mentor text for analyzing illustrations, I will forever leave it to the end of the year and let my students just enjoy it 🥸

Have you read this book?

#uniquebookrecommendation •

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Amy • 3rd Grade Teacher on July 14, 2021. May be an image of child.
Photo by Amy • 3rd Grade Teacher on July 14, 2021. May be an image of one or more people.
Photo by Amy • 3rd Grade Teacher on July 11, 2021. May be an image of book.

node.text:
This is how I do summer ☀️ I am spending my time on professional development, taking courses on reading comprehension, executive functioning, active listening, and children who are defiant. Even after 15 years of teaching, I’m learning a lot. ☀️ I’m rereading books that resonated with me, and after this year I want to be inspired by them again. ☀️ I’m listening to some educational podcasts that are giving me amazing ideas to use with my students. ☀️ And YES, I’M TEACHING SUMMER SCHOOL and loving it.

I know so many of you are taking full advantage of your summer break by taking a break from all things school related. And that’s WONDERFUL.

I am also very cognizant of the fact that I am in a profession that allows me this time each year to reflect, restore, and reenergize myself for the coming school year. My husband isn’t afforded that luxury.

This is my form of teacher self care ❤️
